results.title: Tahrir Square during the Arab Spring uprising
results.credit_line: Courtesy Los Angeles Times. Copyright 2012, Los Angeles Times
results.brief_description: In 2011, the connectivity and speed of social media seemed promising for society and democracy. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube were integral to mobilising people and coordinating protest movements like the Arab Spring, a series of anti-government protests, uprisings and revolutions.

results.title: Occupy Wall Street protestors in New York City
results.brief_description: In 2011, the connectivity and speed of social media seemed promising for society and democracy. Platforms like Facebook, Twitter and YouTube were integral to mobilising people and coordinating protest movements like Occupy Wall Street, which aims to create greater economic equality.

constellations_primary.name: Fight for your right
constellations_primary.description: Real world revolution and the fictional representations that reflect the struggle for equality in the past, present and dystopian future.

results.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
results.brief_description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

constellations_other.name: Representing disasters
constellations_other.description: The devastating Indian Ocean tsunami was captured by many people on personal devices and home cameras, with the footage broadcast to the world. The event also inspired feature films that are part of a long tradition of disaster films, which often push the boundaries of VFX.

constellations_other.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_other.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.title_for_label: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami
results.description: How the media produces news changed dramatically when bystanders captured the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami on handheld cameras. After obtaining the footage, news outlets circulated it around the globe. Today, social media allows spectators to share footage and images of world events instantly.

results.title: Los Angeles riots
results.brief_description: The beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it’s arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992.
results.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”
description_for_label: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”

results.title: Los Angeles riots
results.brief_description: The beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it’s arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992.

constellations_other.name: Rodney King LA Riots
constellations_other.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape and became what is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet. It was a catalyst for the 1992 LA riots, which has influenced media ever since.

results.description: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”
description_for_label: The brutal beating of Rodney King by the LAPD was caught on amateur videotape by George Holliday. Broadcast widely by news outlets, it is arguably the first video of police brutality to go viral before the internet and the policemen’s acquittal was a catalyst for the Los Angeles riots in 1992. Five days into the rioting and social unrest, King himself appeared on TV, pleading with the public, “Can we all get along?”

results.title: Production shot from Essie Coffey’s My Survival as an Aboriginal
results.brief_description: In the late 1970s, Essie Coffey’s My Survival as an Aboriginal used the documentary form as a political act of resistance. Almost 30 years later, Rachel Perkins’ documentary First Australians continued to correct history and create change.
results.title_for_label: Production shot from Essie Coffey’s My Survival as an Aboriginal

group_siblings.title: Film still from John Heyer’s The Back of Beyond

results.title: Film still from John Heyer’s The Back of Beyond
results.brief_description: The Realist Film Unit was formed in 1945 and produced social realist documentaries that highlighted workers’ rights and social issues. From 1948, the Shell Film Unit began making trade and educational films and, in 1954, produced John Heyer’s seminal documentary The Back of Beyond.
results.title_for_label: Film still from John Heyer’s The Back of Beyond
results.description: The Realist Film Unit was formed in 1945 and produced social realist documentaries that highlighted workers’ rights and social issues. From 1948, the Shell Film Unit began making trade and educational films and, in 1954, produced John Heyer’s seminal documentary The Back of Beyond.

results.title: Agnès Varda in Les Glaneurs et La Glaneuse (The Gleaners and I)
results.credit_line: Courtesy Zeitgeist Films / Everett Collection Inc. / Alamy
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.

constellations_primary.name: All about Agnes
constellations_primary.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

results.title_for_label: Agnès Varda in Les Glaneurs et La Glaneuse (The Gleaners and I)
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Zeitgeist Films / Everett Collection Inc. / Alamy
